pages:
Regional Technical Assistance Report
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Project Number: 41531 
February 2008 
 
 
   
Supporting the Boao Forum for Asia  
(Financed by the People’s Republic of China Poverty Reduction 
and Regional Cooperation Fund)

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
BFA  –  Boao Forum for Asia 
DMC  –  developing member country 
ECA  –  export credit agency 
OCO  –  Office of Cofinancing Operations 
OREI  –  Office of Regional Economic Integration 
RETA  –  regional technical assistance 
 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Targeting Classification  –  General intervention 
Sector  –  Law, economic management, and public policy  
Subsector  –  Economic management 
Themes  –  Sustainable economic growth, regional cooperation,  
private sector development  
Subthemes  –  Promoting economic efficiency and enabling markets, 
trade and investments, public-private partnerships 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, "$" refers to US dollars. 
 
 
 
 
Head        J. W. Lee, Office of Regional Economic Integration (OREI) 
 
Director       S. Madhur, OREI  
 
 
Team leader      C. Nguyen, Regional Cooperation Specialist, OREI 
Team member    C. Bellinger, Principal Guarantees and Syndications 
 
         Specialist, Office of Cofinancing Operations

1   
I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The  Boao  Forum  for  Asia  (BFA)  was  established  in  2001  to  help  promote  the 
development  goals  of  and  encourage  closer  ties  among  Asian  countries  through  regional 
cooperation and integration. It provides a high-level forum for government officials, business 
leaders, and academics in Asia to discuss important policy issues and views pertaining to 
regional cooperation and integration in Asia and the Pacific.   
 
2.  Since the beginning of the BFA, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) has supported 
regional  policy  dialogue  and  training  programs,  including those  that  facilitate  public-private 
partnerships and training programs for export credit agency (ECA) officials to enhance their 
portfolio management. The partnership between ADB and the BFA was strengthened with the 
signing of a memorandum of understanding on 22 April 2006. The proposed regional technical 
assistance (RETA)1 will help finance the activities of the BFA for 2008 and 2009 to carry out its 
programs in support of regional cooperation and integration in Asia and the Pacific. The RETA 
design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.   
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  Market-led  integration  in  Asia  has  fueled  policy  interest  in  establishing  new  cross-
regional organizations in Asia and the Pacific. However, building political consensus on the 
structure and functions of regional institutions is difficult in Asia and the Pacific, given its diverse 
economics, politics, culture, geographic and demographic conditions. Consequently, building 
regional institutions in Asia and the Pacific is a long-term process that continues to rely on 
intergovernmental relations rather than on supranational institutions.  
 
4.  The  BFA  continues  to  play  a  crucial  role  in  building  trust  and  confidence  among 
governments.  This  requires  strengthening  regional  policy  dialogue  and  disseminating 
information  effectively  among  the  countries  involved.  ADB  has  been  supporting  and  will 
continue to support the BFA in these two areas. In 2007, ADB sponsored a session entitled 
“Accelerating Asian Growth: Evolution of the Asian Economic Community” at the BFA annual 
conference. ADB Vice President Lawrence C. Greenwood moderated the session, which was 
attended by high-level business people and government officials. The session was well-received 
by the participants, and the BFA secretariat subsequently received positive feedback. ADB and 
the BFA also jointly prepared the BFA Annual Report 20072. The report provides comprehensive 
analysis on emerging trends in regional cooperation and integration. It was widely distributed to 
the private sector, media, academia, and policy makers. The report is posted on the websites of 
ADB and the BFA. 
 
5.  ADB will continue to support the BFA in promoting public-private partnerships in the 
region. The BFA has started the critical process of building these relationships by providing 
venues for interaction between governments and businesses at its annual conferences and 
other meetings. As part of their support for public-private partnerships, ADB and the BFA have 
established a partnership in strengthening the institutional capability of developing member 
countries (DMC) in delivering official export credit at competitive rates and managing their 
portfolios. ADB's objective in helping the Asian export-import  banks, particularly those from 
DMCs,  is  to  enable  them  to  have  the  same  opportunities  as  their  export-import  bank 
                                                 
1 The RETA first appeared in ADB Business Opportunities on 4 January 2008. 
2 Boao Forum for Asia, 2007. Progress of Regional Cooperation and Integration in Asia and the Pacific. Annual 
Report 2007. Manila: ADB.

2
counterparts  in  the  developed  world.  The  training  is  also  consistent  with  ADB's  regional 
cooperation and integration strategy to facilitate trade and investment among member countries 
through capacity building. ADB will continue the level of support it has provided to the Asian 
export-import banks and will broaden its scope to cover more staff in those banks, as well as in 
the ECAs in the DMCs that have not benefited from the ADB assistance. 
 
6.  The RETA will continue to support the BFA in strengthening regional policy dialogue and 
building public-private partnerships to enable the DMCs in the region to maximize regional 
cooperation  and  integration  opportunities,  as  well  as  respond  adequately  to  the  related 
challenges.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
7.  This RETA is consistent with ADB’s regional cooperation and integration strategy in 
building stronger partnerships with regional institutions that support cooperative activities in Asia 
and the Pacific.  
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
8.  The expected impact of the RETA will be (i) strengthened regional policy dialogue on  
regional  cooperation  and  integration  issues  such  as  infrastructure,  trade,  and  investment; 
money and finance; and regional public goods; and (ii) improved public-private partnerships on 
regional cooperation and integration issues. 
 
9.  The  expected  outcomes  are  (i)  increased  awareness  of  the  involved  countries  on 
regional  cooperation  and  integration  issues;  and  (ii)  enhanced  capacity  of  selected  Asian 
export-import banks and ECAs on topical issues, including public and private environmental risk 
management,  infrastructure  financing  in  emerging  markets,  new  risk  mitigation  products, 
governments’ management of contingent liabilities, and compliance with financial standards in 
Asia.  
 
10.  The  expected  results  and  outputs  include  (i)  two  sponsored  sessions  on  regional 
economic integration at the BFA annual conferences in April 2008 and April 2009; (ii) a BFA 
annual report (in April 2009); and (iii) training programs on the topics chosen by the export-
import banks and ECAs, with one training session to be held, as recommended, in Boao City, 
People’s Republic of China, back-to-back with the BFA annual conference, or in the ADB 
headquarters in Manila, Philippines. The other training programs will be held in Manila or the 
most  convenient  country  venue  for  the  participants,  which  will  be  identified  during  project 
implementation. Expected trainees are from export-import banks and ECAs of DMCs.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
11.  The RETA will consist of two major activities: (i) support for the BFA conferences and 
annual report preparation, and (ii) training programs to support capacity development. 
 
12.  Support for the BFA Conferences and Annual Report Preparation. The targeted 
audience of the BFA annual conferences includes government, private sector (business and 
others), and academic organizations. ADB and the BFA secretariat will coordinate closely on the 
main themes of the BFA annual conferences for 2008 and 2009.

3   
13.  For the BFA annual conferences, the RETA will allocate funds (for honoraria, travel 
costs, and other related expenses) to engage the services of resource persons and to cover 
other operating costs (venue rental, translator fees, etc). The BFA, in consultation with ADB, will 
regularly review the conference themes, which will be the basis for determining the expertise of 
the resource persons who will be tapped for the training programs. 
 
14.  The BFA Annual Report 2009 will be published jointly by ADB and the BFA. International 
consultants with expertise on the selected themes will be engaged to prepare the report The 
BFA Annual Report 2009 will be posted on the BFA and ADB websites.  
 
15.  Training Programs and Workshops on Export-Import Banks and ECAs. The training 
will  be  held  in  Boao  City,  People’s  Republic  of  China,  at  ADB  headquarters,  or  at  other 
convenient venues. For 2008, two training programs will be conducted under the RETA. Based 
on earlier consultations with the Asian export-import banks, the priority topics for training in 
2007 and 2008, based on the needs of the Asian export-import banks and ECAs, are: (i) legal 
framework  of  each  member  country,  (ii)  internal  controls  of  Asian  ECAs,  (iii)  Asian  ECA 
business reengineering processes, (iv) management of failed projects in Asian ECAs, and (v) 
human resource development in Asian ECAs. This list of priority topics will be updated after the 
meeting of Asian export-import banks in 2009. From the priority topics, a training syllabus will be 
developed. 
 
16.  The training materials will be compiled in a compact disc and disseminated to all DMCs. 
The compilation will also be posted on the Asia Regional Integration Center website. ADB's 
Office of Regional Economic Integration (OREI) and Office of Cofinancing Operations (OCO) 
will implement the RETA. If the training is held in Boao City, ADB will coordinate with the BFA 
secretariat on the arrangements and proceedings for the training. The training programs will be 
assessed after each training course through evaluation and feedback from the participants, 
resource persons, and relevant institutions. This feedback will allow revisions and adjustments 
to the program to reflect the needs of the participants.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
17.  The RETA is estimated to cost $500,000. The RETA will be financed on a grant basis by 
the  Poverty  Reduction  and  Regional  Cooperation  Fund  funded  by  the  Government  of  the 
People’s Republic of China, and will be administered by ADB. It will cover remuneration, travel, 
and per diem for international and national consultants, resource persons, conference-related 
expenditures, travel costs of participants, other training expenditures, publication of the annual 
report and reference materials, equipment rentals, and miscellaneous expenses. A detailed cost 
breakdown and proposed financing plan are in Appendix 2.   
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
18.  The RETA will be executed by ADB and implemented by OREI and OCO, in close 
collaboration with the BFA secretariat. OREI will lead the implementation of the support for the 
BFA annual conferences and annual report, while OCO will lead the implementation of the 
training for the export-import banks and ECAs. The BFA secretariat is expected to be involved, 
particularly in deciding the overall conference themes and logistics and the protocol for the 
training courses.  
 
19.  The RETA is expected to start in February 2008 and be completed in January 2010. 
International consultants will be chosen through a single-sourced selection method and will be

4
engaged intermittently for a cumulative maximum of 4 person-months to draft the BFA annual 
report. Resource persons will be engaged cumulatively for 4 person-months to conduct the 
training programs. One national consultant, who will be engaged intermittently for a maximum of 
8 person-months, will mainly coordinate the training and assist the international consultants in 
the preparation of the BFA annual report. The national consultant will be based in OREI. An 
outline of the terms of reference for the consultants and resource persons is in Appendix 3. ADB 
will engage the consultants on an individual basis and in accordance with its Guidelines on the 
Use  of  Consultants  (April  2007,  as  amended  from  time  to  time)  and  other  arrangements 
satisfactory to ADB for engaging consultants.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
20.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 to be financed on a 
grant  basis  by  the  Poverty  Reduction  and  Regional  Cooperation  Fund  from  the  People's 
Republic of China for Supporting the Boao Forum for Asia, and hereby reports this action to the 
Board.

5

9  Appendix 3 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
 
A.  International Consultant (Trade and Environmental Economist, 4 person-months)  
 
1.  For the drafting of the Boao Forum for Asia (BFA) annual report, the regional technical 
assistance  (RETA)  will  require  consultant(s)  with  expertise  on  international  trade  policies, 
regional economic cooperation, trade negotiations, and free trade agreements in the region; 
environmental management challenges; and other relevant areas.  
 
2.  Under the supervision of the Office of Regional Economic Integration (OREI) staff and in 
consultation with staff of other departments, the consultant will prepare the 2009 BFA annual 
report, following Asian Development Bank (ADB) guidelines. The annual report will cover the 
previous year and will be drafted based on an outline agreed upon by ADB and the BFA. The 
topics of the report will be jointly agreed upon by ADB and the BFA and will be consistent with 
the themes of the BFA annual conferences.  
 
3.  The consultant is expected to perform the following tasks: 
 
(i)  Review relevant reports, documents, and databases of ADB and the BFA. 
(ii)  Consult with relevant ADB staff and networks.  
(iii)  Prepare first draft of the report for review by OREI staff. 
(iv)  Revise the paper based on the initial comments provided by OREI. 
(v)  Submit the revised draft for ADB interdepartmental comments. 
(vi)  Revise draft based on the comments provided by relevant ADB departments and 
submit the final draft of the reAppopertn.d  ix 2 
(vii)  Provide additional information as requested by the editor. 
(viii)  Prepare presentation materials based on the report. 
 
B.  National Consultant (Research and Project Associate, 8 person-months) 
 
4.  The consultant should be an economist with a master’s degree from an internationally 
recognized university and have substantial experience in managing TA projects and providing 
TA for research studies in regional integration. Excellent writing abilities and strong quantitative 
and computer skills are requirements for the assignment. The consultant will be required to work 
in ADB headquarters during the project implementation.  
 
5.  Working under the supervision of the regional cooperation specialist, the consultant will 
perform the following tasks: 
 
(i)  Assist in organizing the BFA’s annual conferences in collaboration with the BFA 
secretariat. 
(ii)  Support the preparation of the annual report for the BFA. 
(iii)  Assist in conducting research on special issues in trade, economic integration, 
and regional cooperation. 
(iv)  Assist in preparing the training program's curricula, materials, and presentation 
papers. 
(v)  Assist in identifying resource persons for training programs. 
(vi)  Prepare the final report on the export-import bank and export credit agency 
training and follow-up activities.

10
Appendix 3 
(vii)  Collect relevant data for the BFA annual report and support the consultants 
working on it in preparing preliminary analysis as appropriate.  
(viii)  Perform other tasks as required by the regional cooperation specialist.  
 
C.  International Resource Persons (Trade and Finance Experts, 4-person months) 
 
6.  The RETA will require the services of at least four resource persons (for about 4 person-
months) who are experts in the priority topics that will be agreed upon and endorsed by the 
Asian export-import banks and export credit agencies for 2008 and 2009.  
 
7.  The resource persons will have the following responsibilities: 
 
(i)  Design and develop training workshops and prepare detailed outlines for them. 
(ii)  Collate and prepare reference and workshop materials for participants. 
(iii)  Conduct the training workshops. 
(iv)  Prepare  training  workshop  activity  reports  that  include  activity  outlines, 
participant  profiles,  responses  and  outcomes,  lessons  learned,  overall 
impressions, evaluations of the workshops in relation to the RETA objective, and 
remaining issues and suggestions for possible follow-up activities.

TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Targeting Classification  –  General intervention 
Sector  –  Law, economic management, and public policy  
Subsector  –  Economic management 
Themes  –  Sustainable economic growth, regional cooperation,
